Outside of Washington, my bill to #EndCorruptionNow seems like a no-brainer. Most people are probably shocked these rules aren‚Äôt already the law. But if we want to restore integrity to the Office of the President, we need to fight for real change to make it happen.

And we shouldn‚Äôt have to beg presidential candidates to see their financial interests. That‚Äôs why my bill to #EndCorruptionNow would require the IRS to release tax returns for Presidential candidates from the previous 8 years & during each year in federal office.

Former Presidents & other Washington bigwigs shouldn‚Äôt be able to cash in on their connections with high-powered lobbying jobs. My bill to #EndCorruptionNow would place a lifetime ban on lobbying by fmr Presidents (& VPs, members of Congress, federal judges, & cabinet members).

The President also shouldn‚Äôt be able to put his or her lobbyist friends in charge of running federal agencies. My bill to #EndCorruptionNow slams shut the revolving door so no more coal & gas lobbyists can be put in charge of protecting our clean air & water.

My #EndCorruptionNow bill would make sure all govt employees ‚Äì including unpaid White House staff, even family-member advisors to the President ‚Äì are forced to comply with govt ethics & conflict of interest rules.

Presidents shouldn‚Äôt be able to own companies or hotels on the side & use their office to make a fortune. My bill to #EndCorruptionNow would require the President to place his/her assets, including businesses & commercial real estate, into a blind trust to be sold off.

Donald Trump is the most corrupt President in modern US history. But Trump didn‚Äôt cause the rot in Washington ‚Äì he‚Äôs just the biggest, stinkiest example of a system that no longer works for the people. That‚Äôs why this #PresidentsDay, I‚Äôm fighting for my bill to #EndCorruptionNow.

I‚Äôve witnessed the devastation and destruction in #PuertoRico first hand. The Senate must pass the critical disaster relief aid bill approved by the House. #OurFellowAmericans are suffering and cannot wait any longer.(7/7)

Our last stop was a center for displaced individuals and families. While there, I spoke with the mental health professionals about they care they are giving to so many. Funding must be dedicated to helping #PuertoRico rebuild, and also to help its people recover. (6/7) http://pbs.twimg.com/media/ERBatQhX0AMgZyz.jpg

We need to focus on rebuilding the Costa Sur grid quickly, but also make sure that it is resilient, and environmentally sustainable. This power plant is just one example of the critical infrastructure that still needs to be repaired across #PuertoRico. (5/7)

Then we visited the Costa Sur power plant. It services 20% of #PuertoRico, but is badly damaged and is still offline. Puerto Rico‚Äôs electric grid is dangerously vulnerable now & as we head into hurricane season, that‚Äôs a troubling thought. (4/7) http://pbs.twimg.com/media/ERBasYZXUAE07nl.jpg

Next we visited a temporary school & spoke to the principal. She and many others are dedicated to servicing students in wake of damage to  schools. We need to make sure these facilities & programs are getting the funds they desperately need so children continue to learn. (3/7) http://pbs.twimg.com/media/ERBar0wXUAE6zjE.jpg

Our first stop was a school in Southern #PuertoRico that was badly hit. Agripina Seda School Guanica is a reminder that so many children have been impacted by #PuertoRico‚Äôs natural disasters. Many are now learning in temporary schools that lack critical resources. (2/7) http://pbs.twimg.com/media/ERBarPTXsAAMzL-.jpg
